ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: 1. Functional analysis topics including Banach spaces, lp and Lp, spectrum, Hilbert spaces, Fourier series, Baire category, principle of uniform boundedness, open mapping, Hahn-Banach, spectral theorem for compact self-adjoint operators. 2. How to be a mathematician. 3. An infinite number of memes, including "kitchen recipes belong in the kitchen" and the "big potato theorem".
Understanding of Hilbert + Banach spaces, important examples and theorems around them.
Infinite dimensional linear algebra, Fourier Analysis, ergodic theory
My problem solving skills definitely improved, and I learned a lot about functional analysis and general intuition in mathematics
I developed a much greater understanding of how to intuit infinite dimensional spaces and their properties.

Banach and Hilbert spaces; orthogonal projection theorem, and when the infimum distance is attained on various spaces; spectra of linear operators, properties (closeness via von Neumann series), special cases (e.g. self-adjointness, unitary);  Fourier series (a lot) and ergodicity; finally, the big three (or four?), stemming from Baird Category Theorem: Principle of Uniform Boundedness (PUB), Open Mapping Theorem (and also Closed Graph Theorem), and Hahn-Banach (for real, separable Hilbert spaces at least). Also spectral theorem for self-adjoint, compact linear operators on a real, separable Hilbert space. Some other stuff sprinkled in.

Fourier series

The major concepts in functional analysis, along with some linear algebra review as it generalized to infinite dimensions. Started with isometries and linear operators, proof of spectral theorem in finite dimensions (a very intuitive one using compactness that would later generalize sometimes to infinite dimensions), compactness and continuity, polar decomposition and conceptualizing the unit ball in relation to the norm and how its impacted by continuous linear operators. Moved to study l^p, L^p, C function classes, arzela ascoli, Banach spaces, linear operators and adjoints, some spectral theory in infinite dimensions. Then Hilbert spaces, projection theorem and conceptualizing functions as hyperplanes defining their level sets leading to representation theorem. Then proving fundamental Fourier analysis results, like density of trig polynomials and thinking about uniform convergence and Dini criterion and isometric isomorphism from separable Hilbert spaces into l2. Then a little foray into ergodic theory. Then using dual spaces of Banach spaces to generalize some things specific to Hilbert spaces, and derive more properties. This led us into weak convergence, weak boundedness, Baire category, open mapping theorem, closed graph theorem, principle of uniform boundedness. We then had tools to characterize precompact sets and weak convergence in most l^p and L^p spaces, making analogs to Arzela ascoli. Finally looked at compact operators and proved a generalization of spectral theory to infinite dimensions for compact symmetric operators, with the similar proof outline as beginning of year but replacing compactness with weak compactness that holds in infinite dimensions. We also did some forays into Sobolev spaces and PDEs.

Overall most importantly Schlag teaches you how to think about math. I never appreciated it the same until I took this class, now everything kind of fits with a certain geometric intuition. If you want to understand math, take classes with Schlag.

I learned about Banach spaces, hilbert spaces, spectral theory, Fourier series, ergodic theorem, Baire category and its applications, compact operators, the spectral theorem for compact self adjoint operators, Hahn banach
Fourier series, lp and Lp spaces, compact operators, weak convergence, Banach and Hilbert space theorems, whatever Professor Schlag thought was cool

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This is the best course I've taken at Yale. No improvements are necessary. Maybe have some more problem sets towards the end so we can get more practice with the concepts.
Excellent course, easily my favorite math course I've taken. Can't recommend it enough.

Stregths + Weakness depends on perspective:  
1) Schlag , in my opinion, is the best math professor I have had at yale ( beside Charles Smart), however his teaching style is not for everyone. He will often just talk through proofs, or maybe say some things are obvious, so you will have to fill in the gaps, in your notes( unless you are an auditory learner) 
2) Problem sets- The problem sets are great but very very challenging. The grader for the course was great, he offered feedback if you got something wrong without killing your grade

Strengths: content is amazing and psets are a very good way to learn

No weaknesses
Extremely strong course, primarily because of the professor. The syllabus is also quite good, and follows a logical progression through the subject matter.

This course had excellent lectures and enlightening exercises on the homework. The text by luenberger had great exercises, but online notes or a secondary textbook to reference proofs from in class could have been helpful.

Strengths: Professor Schlag, and his infinite wisdom and patience
Weaknesses: Lack of online course notes. If you miss a class, you miss a lot of material. Prof. Schlag should consider having a student note taker, so he can continue to lecture spontaneously while making sure his lectures are transcribed.
Schlag is the best lecturer in the math department.  The homework was manageable and interesting
Professor Schlag is brilliant and cares a lot about teaching

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Just know that this class is really hard and really challenging. Be really good at analysis and linear algebra.  It took over most aspects of my life this semester, but I loved it, so I don't regret it at all. This class helped me find inner peace. Professor Schlag is the best. His lectures are *electric*. He strolls into each class with nothing but some coffee, chalk, and his massive brain. His lectures are like watching a true mathematician at work discovering interesting theorems and proofs. Furthermore, his office hours are wonderful as he makes sure each student has their confusions worked out.
Absolutely, this was a fantastic course and I can't recommend it enough. Workload is relatively high (as it always will be in a challenging topic) but it never felt unmanageable.

Yes, but with Caution!! There is really not one single textbook for this course, Schlag seems to come up with proofs as he lectures and often just talks through them while not writing the proof in full detail, so if you are someone who needs to take good notes and then look over them to understand the material, then this class might be overwhelming.
Yes 100% Schlag is a fantastic lecturer and the problem sets and exams are very manageable
Yes! If you get the end of the real analysis track or just decide to skip to the end and rely on your intuition like me, its a fantastic course!
Yes, this class filled in gaps in my understanding from previous courses, and it taught me some new ways to approach problems. The material is very interesting and feels extremely well motivated.
Absolutely. You will learn so much if Prof. Schlag is teaching.

I said more in the what I learned section but I give highest recommendation. Repeating from there, Schlag teaches you how to think about math. I never appreciated it the same until I took this class, now everything kind of fits with a certain geometric intuition. If you want to understand math, take classes with Schlag.

This content also comes up a lot in higher math and its important to really understand it which is what youll get from this class. Also engaging lecturer
Yes.  Schlag is incredible and the material is super cool.  Very geometric.  Lots of good applications in data science too.
Yes, one of the best math classes I have taken at Yale
